112084 S2468-8231(21)00700-8 10.1016/j.mcat.2021.112084 Fig. 1 Calculation model of pristine, Na+ poisoned and H2SO4 modified MCC catalyst in Lewis acid (A) and Brønsted acid model (B) showing the top view. Grey, blue, brown, red, and yellow balls represent Cr, Co, Mn, O, and S atoms, respectively, and this color scheme will be used throughout. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NOx conversion and N2 selectivity for (a) fresh-MCC, (b) 0.2Na-MCC, (c) 0.5Na-MCC, and (d) 1Na-MCC. Reaction conditions: [NOx] = 500 ppm, [NH3] = 500 ppm, [O2] = 3.6%, N2 balance, GHSV = 112,000 h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 NOx conversion (A) and N2 selectivity (B) over MCC catalyst modified by sulfuric acid with different concentrations (0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.5 M); NOx conversion (C) N2 selectivity (D) over (a) fresh MCC, (b) 0.1S-MCC, (c) 1Na-MCC, and (d) 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts. Reaction conditions: [NOx] = 500 ppm, [NH3] = 500 ppm, [O2] = 3.6%, N2 balance, GHSV = 112,000 h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns for (a) fresh MCC, (b) 0.1S-MCC, (c) 1Na-MCC, and (d) 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for (a) fresh MCC, (b) 0.1S-MCC, (c) 1Na-MCC, and (d) 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Representative XPS spectra for the Mn 2p3/2, Co 2p3/2, Cr 2p3/2, S 2p and O 1s regions of (a) fresh MCC, (b) 0.1S-MCC, (c) 1Na-MCC, and (d) 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (A) NH3-TPD profiles for (a) MCC, (b) 0.1S-MCC, (c) 1Na-MCC, and (d) 1Na+-0.1S-MCC catalysts; (B) Normalized integration area from NH3-TPD profiles. Low-temperature NH3-selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) catalysts with enhanced resistance to alkali-metal compounds are urgently needed for glass furnace, biomass boilers, etc. flue gases denitrification. A sulfuric acid pretreatment approach, which would be more widely applicable relative to the metal oxides addition method at present, was carefully explored for the excellent MnCoCrOx (MCC) catalyst in this work. The catalytic performance tests show that the decrease in de-NOx efficiency and N2 selectivity caused by Na+ poisoning could be well alleviated via H2SO4 pretreatment. 0.1 M sulfuric acid-treated 1 wt.% Na+ poisoned MnCoCrOx (0.1S-1Na-MCC) catalyst still exhibits a broad T90 (the temperature when de-NOx efficiency reaches 90%) window between 199 and 400 °C. The characterization results demonstrate that H2SO4 pretreatment well restrains the blockage of pore channels and loss of specific surface area caused by Na2O species deposition. A majority of acidity and redox ability of 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst were also retained compared with fresh MCC catalyst, which was essential to the SCR process. Sulfuric acid could introduce excessive Brønsted acid sites and cut the loss of Lewis acid sites effectively by the presence of Na2O. Besides, the as-formed HSO4 − species would serve as acid sites for NH3 adsorption and activation. The above findings provide new insights with respect to improving the tolerance of metal oxides SCR catalyst to alkali metals by tuning the surface physicochemical properties by acid pretreatment. Keywords NH3-SCR Alkali metals Catalyst deactivation Acid pretreatment 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO, NO2, N2O, etc.) are one of the major atmospheric pollutants that cause acid rain, photochemical smog, ozone pollution, and other types of environmental pollution events, as well as serious damage to human health [1]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx by NH3 has been proven to be one of the most efficient and reliable technologies for stationary flue gas denitrification, while the commercialized V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst suffers from poor activity below 300 °C. In addition, the alkali metal (Na, K, etc.) compounds in flue gases from coal-fired plants and industrial boilers usually cause severe de-NOx activity loss and lifespan shortening of the catalyst [2]. Hence, the development of novel superior low-temperature SCR catalysts with enhanced resistance to alkali-metals has attracted much attention recently. One of the effective and widely studied approaches to improve the resistance to alkali-metals is introducing a new component as a buffer to capture alkali-metal cations. Wang et al. [3,4] designed a ternary Cu/TiO2-Nb catalyst with excellent low-temperature activity and resistance to potassium. The as-formed Nb-OH and Nb=O sites were responsible for the trapping of K species, and therefore isolated Cu2+ remained the SCR activity. Zhang et al. [5] found that the MoO3 submonolayer over Fe2O3/MoO3/TiO2 catalyst could capture Na species and protect Fe2O3 species from being poisoned by sodium sulfate. Zha et al. [6,7] introduced hollandite Mn-Ti oxides onto Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst, and CeO2 onto Cu/H-SAPO-34 catalyst. The results showed that Mn-Ti oxides could capture the alkali metal, and CeO2 assisted the H-SAPO-34 support in capturing K species, thus alleviating the deactivation of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst. Admittedly, the sacrificing strategy could greatly improve the resistance of SCR catalyst to alkali-metal cations, while the effectiveness highly relies on the additive selected. Up to now, an array of superior low-temperature SCR catalysts has been well developed [8,9], while their resistance to alkali metals remains to be improved. In this regard, the exploration of a more widely applicable antipoisoning enhancement method is of great significance. The acidity impairment resulting from alkali-metal cations assume the main responsibility for catalyst deactivation [10]. The acid sites, especially the Bronsted acid sites, were very easily destroyed by alkali-metals. In the case of the commercialized V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst [11], the H atom of V-OH group of the catalyst was destroyed and a V-O-Na or V-O-K structure was formed. This inhibits the adsorption and activation of NH3 molecules over the catalyst, and the SCR process was therefore severely hindered. It was found that sulfate species over the catalyst were beneficial to protect the active sites. SO4 2−/TiO2 supported CeO2-SnO2 [12] and TiO2-supported Fe2(SO4)3 [13] catalysts demonstrate excellent resistance to potassium ions because they could induce SO4 2− migrating from the bulk phase to the surface to bind with it, thus protecting the active sites from being damaged. The resistance to K+ over Ce/TNTs catalyst could be improved by the modification of sulfuric acid because the activity of adsorbed NH3 and NOx species could be preserved through tuning the balance of acidity and basicity [14]. The H2SO4 pretreated CeO2-TiO2/P25 catalyst could improve its anti-K poisoning ability, and the modified catalyst exhibited strong tolerance towards H2O + SO2 after potassium poisoning [15]. The above researches suggest that sulfuric acid pretreatment was helpful to enhance the resistance to alkali-metals of the SCR catalysts, in addition to poisoned catalysts regeneration. Manganese and cobalt-based metal oxides showed excellent low-temperature SCR activity and promising application prospects [16,17]. Recently, we found the novel MnCoCrOx spinel-type catalysts exhibited broad a T90 operating temperature range of 166-393°C with good resistance to SO2 and H2O [18,19]. In this work, the poisoning effects of Na+ on the catalytic performance for the superior MnCoCrOx (denoted as MCC) catalyst were evaluated. The poisoned Na+ concentrations were set to 0.2–1 wt.%. Besides, the effects of H2SO4 treatment were studied, and the concentrations of the H2SO4 used to modify the catalyst were set to 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 M. Furthermore, the SCR performance for fresh MCC catalyst, Na+ poisoned catalysts, H2SO4 pretreated catalysts, and Na+ poisoned after H2SO4 pretreatment catalysts were tested and compared. The physicochemical property changes were characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). Besides, density functional theory (DFT) was performed to investigate the acidity of the catalysts and oxygen vacancy formation process. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalysts preparation MnxCo1-xCr2O4 catalysts were prepared via sol-gel methods [20]. x mmol manganese nitrates, 1-x mmol cobalt nitrates, and 2 mmol chromium nitrates were dissolved in deionized water and stirred vigorously. Subsequently, 3.6 mmol citric acid monohydrate was added and the mixed solution was stirred at 90 °C until a viscous syrup formed. Then, the syrup was transferred to an oven to obtain the primary products. The final test samples were achieved via calcining the primary products under air at 600 °C for 4 h. The sodium poisoned MCC catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation. Na2CO3 was chosen to be the precursor, and the loading weight was 0.2–1 wt.% [2,3]. The sample was fully dried in the oven at 110 °C for 2 h. Finally, the solid sample was then transferred to a tube furnace and calcined at 500 °C under air for 3 h to obtain the final sample. For convenience, x Na is used in the following to refer to the MnxCo1-xCr2O4 catalysts loaded with x wt.% Na2CO3. The acidification catalyst was prepared as follows: 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 M sulfuric acid was prepared, and a certain MCC catalyst was impregnated in the sulfuric acid for 6 h. Then, the supernatant was removed and the wet acidification MnxCo1-xCr2O4 sample was obtained. Finally, the sample was fully dried for further tests (denoted as x S-MCC). The sodium poisoned catalyst after sulfuric acid treatment was obtained via impregnating the x S-MCC in Na2CO3 solution, after which the water was completely evaporated. The solid sample was then transferred to a tube furnace and calcined at 500 °C under air atmosphere for 3 h to obtain the final sample (denoted as x S-y Na-MCC). The catalysts were sieved into 40–60 mesh and evaluated in the fixed-bed quartz reactor. The concentrations of NO and NO2 were recorded with a NOx analyzer (Thermo Scientific 42i-HL), and the concentration of NH3 and N2O was recorded with an FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Nicolet 6700) equipped with a gas cell. The de-NOx efficiency and N2 selectivity were calculated by the following equations, and the value used in the equation was the average value of three times. (1) De − N O x efficiency = ( 1 − [ NO ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t [ NO ] i n + [ N O 2 ] i n ) × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity = ( 1 − 2 × [ N 2 O ] [ N O x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N O x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out ) × 100 % 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray diffractometry (XRD, Ultima IV XRD) was carried out with a scanning rate of 2 ° min−1 in the range of 5–80°, and with 0.5° min−1 in the range of 30–40°. Raman spectra were recorded by Jobin-Yvon LabRamHRUV with a 514 nm laser, and the scanning range was 100–1000 cm−1. N2 adsorption-desorption was carried out with Micromeritics ASAP-2460 at 77 K cooled by liquid nitrogen. The specific surface area was determined by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and pore diameter and volume were calculated by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The micrographs of the catalysts and the elements distribution mapping were obtained with a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Zeiss SIGMA HD) equipped with an energy dispersion spectrometer (EDS). The surface atomic ratio and valence were obtained with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250XI), calibrated by adventitious C 1s peak at 248.8 eV. NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) was carried out on a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics, AutoChem II 2920) with a TCD. Prior to the tests, the samples were treated at 300 °C under N2 condition for 0.5 h, and then cooled to ambient temperature. Subsequently, the samples were exposed to 10% vol. NH3/He for 1 h, and pure He was purged to remove the residual NH3. Finally, the profiles were recorded by ramping the temperature at 10 °C min−1–500 °C. In situ DRIFTS were performed on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 IR spectrometer equipped with a Harrick in situ cell with a liquid nitrogen-cooled mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. Recordings were made in the range of 1000–2000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to each test, all samples were pre-treated by heating at 400 °C for 0.5 h under N2 gas stream and then cooled to ambient temperature to obtain background spectra. The catalyst was exposed to a 500 ppm NH3 gas stream at 30 °C for 60 min. Then, N2 was introduced and the residual reaction gas in the line was purged for 0.5 h. Finally, desorption experiments were performed in which continuous N2 was ramped up at a rate of 10°C/min, and spectra were recorded from 100 to 400 °C. 2.3 DFT calculation methods All the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with Dmol3 implemented in Materials Studio 2019 [21]. Generalized gradient approximation (GGA)-PBE functional was used to calculate exchange-correlation potential [22,23]. The SCF convergence criteria of geometry optimization were set to 1.0 × 10−5 Ha on the energy, 0.002 Ha/Å on the force, and 0.005 Å on the displacement. The molecular orbitals were expanded using a double numerical basis set with polarization functions (DNP). The core electrons of Mn, Co, and Cr atoms were treated with DFT semi-core pesudopotentials (DSPP). A p(2 × 2) slab model exposing (1 0 0) crystal plane of Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4 was built, and the vacuum layer was set to be 15 Å. The bottom four atomic layers of the model were fixed while the top two layers were fully relaxed. Monkhorst-Pack k points grid was 3 × 3 × 1 for the geometry optimization and energy calculation. According to the XPS results in our previous study, the atomic Mn/Co ratio was 1/4.6. Therefore, one of the Co atoms at the surface of the DFT model was substituted with a Mn atom to mimic the experimental condition in this study. Furthermore, DFT calculations were carried out on Lewis acid sites (denoted as L-model) and Brønsted acid sites (denoted as B-model), respectively, to understand the Na poisoning and H2SO4 pretreatment effects on the acidity of catalysts. The calculation models are displayed in Fig. 1. The adsorption energy (Ea) and formation energy of oxygen vacancy (Ev) were obtained using the following equations: (3) E a = E t o t a l − ( E s u b + E a d s ) (4) E v = E v s + 1 2 E O 2 ( g a s ) − E f s Where Etotal and Esub are the total energy of the system after and before adsorption, respectively. Eads is the energy of the adsorbate, i. e. NH3 or Na2O in this work. Evs and Efs are the energy of the system with and without an oxygen vacancy, respectively. The extracted oxygen atom from the full system was assumed to form an oxygen molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SCR performance of Na+ poisoned MCC catalysts The effects of various sodium concentrations (0, 0.2, 0.5, and 1 wt.%) on the de-NOx efficiency of MCC catalyst were investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 2A. It is seen that the addition of sodium had a significant inhibitory effect on the catalytic activity, and the higher the loading, the more pronounced the inhibition. The T90 window of fresh MCC catalyst was 166–393 °C. When 0.2 wt.% sodium carbonate was added, the de-NOx efficiency was slightly adversely affected, and the T90 was narrowed to 176–375 °C; as the sodium carbonate ratio increased to 1 wt.%, the de-NOx efficiency further decreased and the T90 became 223–296 °C. The results demonstrate that the presence of Na+ in the flue gas would lead to the poisoning of MCC catalyst, and the higher the concentration the more severe the loss in efficiency. The effect of sodium poisoning on the N2 selectivity was also investigated. The results show that sodium poisoning slightly affected the N2 selectivity of the MCC catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2B, when 0.2 and 0.5 wt.% sodium carbonate were added, the N2 selectivity of which was still very close to that of the fresh catalyst. When the sodium carbonate addition was increased to 1 wt.%, the N2 selectivity distinctly dropped, but it remained nearly 100% below 300 °C. 3.2 H2SO4 pretreatment In order to enhance the Na+ poisoning resistance of MCC catalyst, dilute sulfuric acid was used to modify the catalyst acidic sites further to neutralize the alkali metal effects. The effect of various concentrations of H2SO4 on de-NOx efficiency for fresh MCC catalyst was investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 3A and B. It is seen that compared to the fresh catalyst, the de-NOx efficiency for the MCC catalyst treated with 0.05 and 0.1 M H2SO4 slightly improved, especially in the temperature range above 300 °C. While the fresh MCC catalyst was treated with 0.2 M H2SO4, its de-NOx efficiency decreased by 10–20% in the temperature range below 300 °C, whereas the efficiency remains ca. 100% above 300 °C. While the H2SO4 concentration increased to 0.5 M, the MCC catalyst basically lost its activity. It is possibly because the crystalline structure of the catalyst was severely damaged or the metal active sites on the surface were sulphated [24]. Besides, the concentration of H2SO4 hardly affects the N2 selectivity (Fig. 3B). The results above indicate that the de-NOx efficiency change for MCC catalyst depends on the H2SO4 concentration used. Therefore, the optimum H2SO4 concentration for the MCC catalyst pretreatment was determined to be 0.1 M. The modified catalyst was then further investigated for its resistance to Na+ poisoning. The de-NOx efficiencies for fresh, H2SO4 pretreated MCC catalysts and the changes as Na+ species was introduced were compared, the results of which are shown in Fig. 3C. It is be seen that the resistance to sodium poisoning of MCC catalyst significantly improved after H2SO4 pretreatment. Although the de-NOx efficiency did not fully recover to the level of the fresh catalyst, its broad T90 window remained in the temperature range of 199–400°C, which was generally better than that of the 0.5 wt.% sodium poisoned MCC catalyst (188–342 °C). Compared to 1Na-MCC catalyst, N2 selectivity for H2SO4 pretreated 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst also increased (Fig. 3D). The denitrification performance for H2SO4 pretreated catalyst inherited the excellence of 0.1S-MCC catalyst in the temperature range above 300 °C, outperforming the fresh MCC catalyst. The above results demonstrate that the pretreatment of MCC catalyst with an appropriate concentration of sulfuric acid can greatly improve its resistance to Na+ poisoning. 3.3 Textual properties Fig. 4 shows the crystalline structure changes of the MCC catalyst characterized by XRD before and after Na+ poisoning and acid pretreatment. It is seen that both Na+ poisoned and sulfuric acid treated MCC catalyst showed similar diffraction peaks with fresh catalyst, suggesting that the spinel structure of MCC catalyst was well retained. However, the peak intensities of 0.1S-MCC, Na-MCC, and 0.1S-Na-MCC catalysts became weaker and the half-peak widths increased slightly as compared with the fresh MCC catalyst. This indicates that the crystallinity of the sodium salt or sulfuric acid treated samples decreased and the grain size became smaller. Besides, new peaks at 24.2° and 54.9° emerged on 1Na-MCC and 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts, which was attributed to Na2O (PDF# 03-1074) phase. The peak shapes and positions of the Na-MCC and 0.1S-Na-MCC catalysts were very close to each other, whereas the Na2O diffraction peaks of the latter were weaker than those of the former. This indicates that the sulfuric acid-treated MCC catalyst inhibited Na2O binding to the catalyst, thus alleviating the deactivation of the catalyst to a certain extent. The isotherms shown in Fig. 5A demonstrate type IV shape with H3-type hysteresis loop for all the catalysts samples in the relative pressure range of P/P0 = 0.4–1.0. This indicates that there were mainly slit mesopores in the catalysts derived from flake particle accumulation and the pore structures hardly changed treated with H2SO4 or Na+ species. As shown in Fig. 5B, the pore diameter for fresh MCC catalyst fell in the range of 1–10 nm. In contrast, the pores in the diameter range of 10-20 nm emerged with H2SO4 pretreatment, and the pore volume greatly increased. The Na+ species slightly changed the pore diameter distribution, while it caused severe loss of volume. Thanks to H2SO4 pretreatment, the process of Na+ species deposition onto the inner pores of the catalysts was hindered, and the newly emerged pores might also compensate for the volume loss caused by Na+ species. The changes of specific surface area, mean pore size, and pore volume of the sodium poisoned and sulfuric acid pretreated MCC catalysts are listed in Table 1 . The results showed that the specific surface area (84.7 m2 g−1), average pore diameter (7.54 nm) and pore volume (0.174 cm3 g−1) of the catalysts decreased to 64.1 m2 g−1, 7.25 nm, and 0.142 cm3 g−1 after sodium poisoning, respectively, which should be due to the blockage of some pore channels of the catalysts by the presence of Na2O. Sulfuric acid had a significant pore expansion effect on the fresh MCC catalyst, and the specific surface area (104.2 m2 g−1), average pore size (8.71 nm), and pore volume (0.227 cm3 g−1) of 0.1S-MCC were significantly increased. The elevated specific surface area of the catalyst exposed more active sites and could accommodate higher amounts of Na+ species. Therefore, the de-NOx efficiency for 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst was increased relative to 1Na-MCC catalyst, and the Na+ tolerance was greatly enhanced. The specific surface area (75.4 m2 g−1), and pore volume (0.161 cm3 g−1) of 0.1S-1Na-MCC were slightly lower than those of the fresh MCC catalyst but higher than those of the Na-MCC catalyst, which is consistent with the sequence of catalytic activities. 3.4 XPS analysis The surface elements of the catalysts were analyzed by XPS and the results are shown in Fig. S1 and Table S1. It is seen that the elemental composition of each catalyst was consistent with the elemental composition of the precursors used in the catalyst preparation. Co, Mn, Cr, and O species were detected in all catalyst samples, except for the 0.1S-MCC catalyst where S elements were detected, 1Na-MCC catalyst where Na elements were detected, and 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts were present for both S and Na elements. The relative content of each element after normalization was compiled in Table 2 . As determined in our previous study, Mn and Co species played a key role in the NH3-SCR performance of MnxCo1-xCr2O4 catalysts [18]. The atomic ratio of Co (6.93%), Mn (1.37%), and O (64.15%) species, at the surface of poisoned MCC catalyst in the presence of Na species (2.58%), were distinctly lower than at the fresh MCC catalyst (7.10%, 1.48%, and 66.75%, respectively). Besides, the Co content of sulfuric acid-treated catalyst (9.76%) was found to be higher than of MCC (7.10%) and 1Na-MCC (6.93%), while a slight change in Mn content. The concentration of surface oxygen species was slightly lower than that of fresh MCC catalyst (66.75%) for all sodium-poisoned or acid-treated samples. This helps to explain why 0.1 M H2SO4 would positively affect but Na+ negatively affect the fresh MCC catalyst. By comparing 1Na-MCC and 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalysts, it is seen that the exposure of Mn and Co active sites of the MCC catalysts treated with 0.1 M H2SO4 remained essentially similar to or even higher than that of the fresh catalyst, and inhibiting Na+ adsorption on the catalyst surface (1.01% for 0.1S-1Na-MCC vs. 2.58% for 1Na-MCC). This is consistent with the conclusion obtained from the XRD analysis that the amount of Na2O production was significantly reduced after the acid treatment of the catalyst. The XPS spectra of Co 2p3/2, Mn 2p3/2, Cr 2p3/2, O 1s, and S 2p were, respectively deconvoluted, and the results were shown in Fig. 6 and Table 2. Mn 2p3/2 was fitted into Mn2+ (640.0–640.5 eV), Mn3+ (641.2–641.8 eV), and Mn4+ (642.5–643.3 eV) species [25,26]. Co 2p3/2 was fitted into Co3+ (780.4–780.7 eV), and Co2+ (782.4–783.0 eV) with a satellite peak at 786.8 eV [27]. Cr 2p3/2 was fitted into Cr5+ (578.9–579.2 eV), Cr3+ (576.7–576.9 eV), and Cr2+ (575.5–575.7 eV) species [28,29]. O 1s was fitted into three peaks for surface chemisorbed oxygen (531.3–531.5 eV, denoted as Osurface), lattice oxygen (530.3–530.5 eV, denoted as Olattice), and surface adsorbed hydroxyls or molecular water (532.2–532.4 eV, denoted as OH) [30]. S 2p was fitted into two peaks of HSO4 − (168.4 eV) and SO4 2− (169.8 eV) [31]. Mn4+, Co3+, Cr5+, and Osurface species on MCC catalyst were superior for enhanced NH3-SCR performance [32,33]. As shown in Table 2, the relative contents of Mn4+, Co3+, Cr5+, and Osurface of the Na+ poisoning catalysts were lower than the fresh catalysts, and therefore the SCR catalytic efficiency for 1Na-MCC catalyst was greatly decreased as well. The analysis of the S 2p spectra showed that the catalyst samples modified by sulfuric acid provided a large amount of HSO4 − groups (0.1S-MCC, 59.4%; 0.1S-1Na-MCC, 58.9%). It was reported [18] that SO4 2− is highly susceptible to the formation of HSO4 − with Brønsted acid sites in the presence of surface water molecules. Thus, a certain amount of Brønsted acid sites should be generated. Based on the above results, it is speculated that the improved anti-Na+ poisoning performance of the 0.1S-MCC catalyst was also because the Mn4+, Cr5+ and chemisorbed oxygen species were well maintained at a level close to or even higher than that of the fresh catalyst after Na2O poisoning. 3.5 NH3-TPD analysis The amount and strength of acid sites on the catalyst are closely related to NH3 adsorption and activation, further affecting the de-NOx activity of the catalyst [34]. Hence, NH3-TPD was carried out to study the acidity changes of MCC catalyst after sulfuric acid pretreatment and Na+ poisoning, and the results were shown in Fig. 7. The desorption bands below and above 250 °C could be ascribed to weak and strong acid sites, respectively [35]. It is noted that the amounts of acid sites of MCC catalyst increased with 0.1 M sulfuric acid pretreatment and the acid strength was also enhanced significantly. For fresh MCC catalyst, a strong NH3 desorption band at 105 °C and a broad band centered at 347 °C were found. In comparison, the bands for 0.1S-MCC catalysts shifted to a higher temperature, and a band at 448 °C attributed to the strong acid site emerged. Besides, the total amount of acid sites increased by ca. 24% relative to the fresh catalyst. For sodium poisoned 1Na-MCC catalyst, the total acid amounts were reduced by ca. 33% relative to the fresh catalyst. Specifically, the strong acid band at 347 °C almost completely disappeared, although and the weak acid band shifted from 105 to 114 °C. The worse acidity of 1Na-MCC catalyst led to its inferior de-NOx activity. For the 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst, it was found that some medium acid sites centered at 249 °C emerged, which was not observed for 1Na-MCC catalyst. Around 84% of the total acid sites of the fresh catalyst were preserved, and it was ca. 25% higher than that of the 1Na-MCC catalyst. This suggests that H2SO4 pretreatment helped preserve the strong acid sites in the presence of Na+ species, or the HSO4 − species were acid sites themselves. The increased acidity was conducible for the SCR process. Generally, the acidity of the catalysts corresponded well to its de-NOx activity, following the sequence of 0.1S-MCC > fresh MCC > 0.1S-1Na-MCC > 1Na-MCC. 3.6 H2-TPR analysis The redox ability of the samples was evaluated and compared via H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 8, the reduction bands greatly changed for the H2SO4-treated and Na+-poisoned MCC catalyst. For the fresh MCC catalyst, the band at around 220 °C could be ascribed to the reduction of Cr5+ to Cr3+ [36], and the band at around 330 °C could be ascribed to the overlaps of the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Co3+ to Co2+ [17]. By contrast, the reduction bands for 0.1S-MCC catalyst changed a little, in addition to the band at 220 °C shifting to 217 °C and the curve area increased. The bands at 220 °C shifted to a higher temperature (238 °C) and the band at around 330 °C fully disappeared for 1Na-MCC catalyst, indicating the redox ability of the catalyst was severely damaged due to Na+ species suppressing the reduction of Mn and Co species. H2SO4 pretreatment was not conducive for alleviating the damage of redox ability, while it helped to reserve the amount of reducible Cr species. 3.7 In situ DRIFT study To further specify the changes in the acidity of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites after Na+ poisoning and sulfuric acid pretreatment, in situ DRIFT was carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 9A. The peaks at 1215–1241 cm−1 and 1601 cm−1 were attributed to symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH3 adsorbed at the Lewis acid site [37–39], and the peaks at 1433 and 1668 cm−1 were attributed to symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + adsorbed at the Brønsted acid sites [40,41]. By comparing the IR band area of the MCC and 1Na-MCC catalysts, it is seen that the presence of Na2O caused the loss of most of the acid sites, especially the Brønsted acid site almost completely lost and the Lewis acid site retained only 37% of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 9B). Hence, the de-NOx activity over the Na-MCC catalyst greatly decreased. Combined with the results of NH3-TPD profiles, it was concluded that the increased amounts of the acid sites mainly stemmed from Brønsted acid sites. The amounts of Brønsted acid sites for 0.1S-MCC catalyst were increased by 43% with the pretreatment of H2SO4, and the Lewis acidity was little affected. For the 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst, H2SO4 pretreatment helped to retain the majority of Lewis (83%) and Brønsted (78%) acid sites relative to the fresh catalyst. Beyond that, a significant increase in the number of nitro compounds (1460 and 1572 cm−1), key intermediates in the SCR process, was observed. The above results help to explain its hardly affected de-NOx activity. Fig. 10 demonstrates the thermal stability of the acid sites of MCC, 0.1S-MCC, 1Na-MCC, and 0.1S-1Na-MCC. It is noted that not only a decrease in the number of acid sites occurred after sodium poisoning, but also the stability of acid sites greatly weakened (Fig. 10A, C). This indicates that Na2O has a very detrimental effect on the surface acidity of the catalysts. Specifically, the Lewis acid sites (1215 cm−1) on fresh MCC catalyst remained to be observed at 300 °C, while the band on 1Na-MCC catalyst completely vanished, and the Brønsted acid sites (1433 cm−1) vanished above 350 °C as well. As shown in Fig. 10B, both the amounts and stability of Brønsted acid sites on MCC catalyst were improved with H2SO4 pretreatment, and the band at 1433 cm−1 was considerably intensified relative to fresh MCC and could still be observed above 350 °C. Besides, it is interesting to notice that the thermal stability of Lewis acid sites was also improved due to the presence of SO4 2- and HSO4 − species, and the stability was also higher than that of the fresh MCC catalyst (Fig. 10B). The enhanced acidity helps to explain why the 0.1S-MCC catalyst exhibited better de-NOx efficiency than fresh MCC at elevated temperatures. Fig. 10D demonstrates the acidity of 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst, both the amounts and stability were superior to that of the unmodified catalyst (Fig. 10A, C). It generally exhibited much greater SCR performance than 1Na-MCC catalyst due to the enhanced surface acidity. However, the severely damaged acidity due to sodium addition could not be fully inhibited by H2SO4 pretreatment, thus a degree of activity loss could still be observed. 3.8 DFT study To obtain the function mechanism of Na+ poisoned and H2SO4 pretreatment on SCR process on a molecular scale, the adsorption behaviors of NH3 were studied on Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites of MCC catalyst in the presence of Na+ and HSO4 −. It was found that Mn sites of MCC catalyst play a major role in the SCR process in our previous study, hence the effects of Na+ species on Mn sites were studied as a representative. As shown in Fig. 11A, the adsorption energy of NH3 adsorbed on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites of pristine catalyst were -1.26 and -0.98 eV, respectively. By contrast, the adsorption energy greatly increased to -0.15 and -0.21 eV in the presence of Na+ species, respectively. This indicates that the presence of Na+ would impair the acidity of MCC catalyst and thus inhibit the process of NH3 adsorption and activation, which is well consistent with the results of NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFTs. Moreover, it is interesting to note that NH3 has a strong infinity with the HSO4 − species, even matched to it adsorbed on the pristine surface. This indicates that HSO4 − species could also serve as acid sites, forming conducive NH4 + species. The NH3 adsorption energies were -0.86 and -0.95 eV on the L-model and B-model of MCC catalyst in the presence of HSO4 − species, respectively. Besides, the adsorption energy was much lower than NH3 adsorbed on the Cr sites covered by HSO4 − species. These results explain that why H2SO4 pretreatment caused enhanced SCR performance for MCC catalyst, because the as formed HSO4 − species compensated the loss of Lewis and Bronsted sites for NH3 adsorption. The formation energies of an oxygen vacancy were calculated to study the effects of Na+ and HSO4 − species on the oxygen species mobility at the surface of MCC catalyst. The calculation models and results were shown in Fig. 11. The formation energy of an oxygen vacancy at the pristine surface of the MCC catalyst was 0.62 eV. In contrast, the formation energies of an oxygen vacancy in the presence of Na+ and HSO4 − were 1.26 and 0.55 eV, respectively. This suggests that the presence of Na+ at the surface of the MCC catalyst inhibited the formation of oxygen vacancy, whereas HSO4 − species could promote the formation of oxygen vacancy. The oxygen vacancies were closely related to the chemisorbed oxygen species. As a result, the DFT results explain why the ratio of Osuraface species followed the sequence of 0.1S-MCC > fresh MCC > 1Na-MCC. 4 Conclusion In summary, the de-NOx activity loss for MnCoCrOx catalyst was mainly resulting from the blockage of inner pores and destruction of acid sites and redox ability by the presence of Na species in the form of Na2O. 0.1 M sulfuric acid pretreatment could greatly enhance the tolerance of MnCoCrOx catalyst to Na+ species and preserve a T90 window of 199–400 °C. The effect mechanism of Na+ species and sulfuric acid on MnCoCrOx catalyst was proposed and depicted in Fig. 12. The main reasons for the improved anti-poisoning ability were summarized as follows: (1) H2SO4 pretreatment could enlarge the inner pores of MnCoCrOx catalyst effectively, and suppress Na species deposition onto the active sites; (2) The contents of conducive Mn4+, Cr5+ and Osurface species of the 0.1S-1Na+-MCC catalyst were well preserved, accompanied with little affected acidity and redox ability for the catalysts. (3) The amount and thermal stability of Brønsted acid sites was greatly improved after sulfuric acid treatment, and the as formed HSO4 − species serve as acid sites for the SCR process. The presented work provides a new understanding for developing the SCR catalyst with excellent Na+ poisoning resistance via the sulfuric acid pretreatment method, which may also inspire the researches for the preparation of the SCR catalyst against other types of alkali and alkaline-earth metals. coredata.dc:description: Low-temperature NH3-selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) catalysts with enhanced resistance to alkali-metal compounds are urgently needed for glass furnace, biomass boilers, etc. flue gases denitrification. A sulfuric acid pretreatment approach, which would be more widely applicable relative to the metal oxides addition method at present, was carefully explored for the excellent MnCoCrOx (MCC) catalyst in this work. The catalytic performance tests show that the decrease in de-NOx efficiency and N2 selectivity caused by Na+ poisoning could be well alleviated via H2SO4 pretreatment. 0.1 M sulfuric acid-treated 1 wt.% Na+ poisoned MnCoCrOx (0.1S-1Na-MCC) catalyst still exhibits a broad T90 (the temperature when de-NOx efficiency reaches 90%) window between 199 and 400 °C. The characterization results demonstrate that H2SO4 pretreatment well restrains the blockage of pore channels and loss of specific surface area caused by Na2O species deposition. A majority of acidity and redox ability of 0.1S-1Na-MCC catalyst were also retained compared with fresh MCC catalyst, which was essential to the SCR process. Sulfuric acid could introduce excessive Brønsted acid sites and cut the loss of Lewis acid sites effectively by the presence of Na2O. Besides, the as-formed HSO4 − species would serve as acid sites for NH3 adsorption and activation. The above findings provide new insights with respect to improving the tolerance of metal oxides SCR catalyst to alkali metals by tuning the surface physicochemical properties by acid pretreatment.
coredata.dc:title: The enhanced resistance to Na+-poisoning of MnCoCrOx SCR catalyst by acidity regulation: The mechanism of sulfuric acid pretreatment
